puzzles.Title: Why do the foods we eat matter?
puzzles.Caption: Leonard Dave, of the Yakama Nation fishes on the Klickitat, a tributary of the Columbia River. The Klickitat is one of the few places in the state where Yakama tribal members still fish for salmon with dip nets on platforms
puzzles.Intro: At this point in the inquiry, you have examined sources that show the many reasons that salmon are important to Pacific Northwest Native Nations. You’ve seen that threats to Native cultures and lifeways take many forms and include new challenges that persist today. Yet, despite adversity Native Nations of the Pacific Northwest continue to protect salmon, exercise sovereignty, and maintain their cultural identity.
puzzles.IntroPrompt: Twelve cards show selected sources from the inquiry. Match each source to it’s corresponding theme and reveal an iconic image.
puzzles.IntroCaption: Celilo means “echo of water on rocks” in the Sahaptin language. Indians fishing at Celilo Falls, ca. 1900.
puzzles.LearningPoints: Salmon is not just a critical food source for Native peoples of the Pacific Northwest; it also reflects their histories and cultures. Organized actions on the part of Native Nations of the Pacific Northwest show agency and ensure cultural survival.
puzzles.LearningPointsPrompt: Now you are ready to begin constructing an argument that addresses the compelling question. Go back and select sources from the inquiry that best support your argument.

Themes.title: Cultures
Themes.definition: Shared beliefs, traditions, and practices of a group.

Themes.title: Threats
Themes.definition: Many man-made changes have devastating and lasting effects on the survival of salmon and impact Native peoples and Nations of the Pacific Northwest.

Themes.title: Actions
Themes.definition: The innovative and culture based steps taken by Native Nations of the Pacific Northwest to rebuild salmon populations and protect their homelands.

Cards.title: Quileute Hook
Cards.caption: Native peoples engineered a variety of tools and techniques to harvest salmon. The hook-and-line method reflects the sustainable practice of taking enough fish for a family or community while leaving healthy, sustainable amounts of fish to spawn and migrate.
Cards.credit: Quileute iron salmon hook, ca.1890. NMAI 057591
Cards.incorrect: Try again. Read the caption and think about the significance of this object to Pacific Northwest Native peoples.

Cards.title: Lisa Wilson Cook
Cards.body: “My dad instilled in me how important the fish was. We spent many hours out on the water, and that is how I related to myself, as a strong person through fishing . . . I know that I’m the person that I am today because of fishing.”
Cards.incorrect: Try again. Think about what Lisa Cook says about the importance of fishing to her and her family.

Cards.title: Michael Marchand
Cards.body: “Salmon has always been essential to our life. We all had jobs to do and most of them centered around salmon. . . . [Salmon] provided everything they needed to live. . . . All their religion and food was salmon. It was the basis for everything.”
Cards.credit: Michael Marchand (Confederated Tribes of Colville Reservation), NMAI Interview, July 2016
Cards.incorrect: Try again. What does Michael Marchand tell you about the role of salmon for his community?

Cards.title: Makah Days
Cards.caption: Makah Days in the mid-1950s. Native Nations of the Pacific Northwest use cedar skewers to pierce, roast, and smoke salmon filets over open pit fires.
Cards.credit: Makah Feast Day, Salmon Bake, ca. 1955. Photograph credited to the Makah Tribe, Source
Cards.incorrect: Try again. What does this convey about the importance of Native food practices?

Cards.title: Carol Craig
Cards.body: “On March 7, 1957, they [the Army Corps of Engineers] closed the concrete gates and the tribal people stood on the side of the hills dressed in regalia and mourning the loss of Celilo Falls. It took seven to eight hours before it was completely flooded over. . .  It was devastating. They thought, after that, that we would lay down our fishing equipment and walk away.”
Cards.incorrect: Try again. Think about the event that Carol Craig is referencing. How did that event impact the communities of Celilo Falls?

Cards.title: Dalles Dam
Cards.caption: Construction of dams requires explosive forces. This blast used more than twenty tons of explosive powder and removed 60,000 cubic yards of basalt.
Cards.credit: The Dalles Dam Blast. Photo by Ray Atkeson
Cards.incorrect: Try again. What are possible consequences for salmon of using explosive forces?

Cards.title: Valerie Segrest
Cards.body: “A reality for many tribal communities is the access to food that we need to be able to heal ourselves from and prevent diseases like diabetes and heart disease is challenging.”
Cards.incorrect: Try again. How does limited access to healthy foods impact individuals and communities?

Cards.title: Logging
Cards.caption: Clear cutting of timber damages salmon habitat in numerous ways. Without the shade and root systems provided by the trees, the water of spawning grounds overheats and silt and runoff damage or destroy spawning areas.
Cards.credit: A Kelly-Springfield logging truck hauls a large fir log along a track-like wooden logging road. Behind the truck are acres of cutover land. Photo by J. Wilbur Sandison, ca. 1925. Photo courtesy of the PEMCO and Stevens Collection, Museum of History and Industry, Seattle. 1983.10.3675.10
Cards.incorrect: Try again. Read the caption. What does clear cutting do to salmon habitats?

Cards.title: Fishing Commissions
Cards.caption: Member nations of intertribal fishing commissions coordinate with state and federal agencies to ensure fair harvesting practices between tribal and nontribal fishers. A key component of their work is educating the general public and policy makers on salmon restoration, treaty fishing rights, and tribal culture.
Cards.credit: Seal of the Columbia River Inter-Tribal Fish Commission (CRITFC). Courtesy of Jeremy Five Crows; Seal of the Northwest Indian Fisheries Commission (NWIFC), courtesy of NWIFC.
Cards.incorrect: Try again. Think about the significance of educating people about salmon restoration, treaty rights, and tribal cultures.

Cards.title: Mel Moon
Cards.body: “Every time we have a governor come and go, or a senator come and go, they come back and they talk to us, and every one of them said, ‘We couldn't have taken care of the resource as good as we did without the tribes.’. . . The tribes have brought a different element of what needs to be done in terms of management.”
Cards.incorrect: Try again. What is Mel Moon saying about the role Native Nations play in resource management?

Cards.title: Carol Craig
Cards.body: “We planted baby fish, they left, they started coming back in numbers. People could not believe it. This was for everybody. Tribal and nontribal people could fish in the Yakima River.”
Cards.incorrect: Try again. Why did salmon begin to return to the Yakima River?

Cards.title: Nancy Shippentower
Cards.body: “It’s the tribes that are putting the fish back in the waters. It’s our people doing that to make sure our livelihood will carry on, that our children will have this opportunity to get into a boat and go fishing so they can eat what they need.”
Cards.incorrect: Try again. Who is taking responsibility for restoring salmon and why is that significant?
